DataElement.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography Evaluation Details Lesion Sequence Number java.lang.Integer
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered. (NCI04):Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.:Particulars considered individually and in relation to a whole._A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.:A serial arrangement in which things follow in logical order or a recurrent pattern.:A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification._Generic value domain for a primitive java dataype that is an Integer (32-bit two's complement).

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
